questions.text:
A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, irritability, and vomiting for 2 weeks. She was born at 36 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. She is at 5th percentile for length and at 3rd percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 49/min. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

138 mEq/L


 K+

3.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

115 mEq/L


 Ammonia
23 μmol/L (N = 11–35)


Urine



 pH

6.9


 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein
negative


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.28


pO2

96 mm Hg


HCO3-
12 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids
Inability of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl-
Inability of the proximal tubule to reabsorb HCO3-
Inability of the distal tubule to secrete H+

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by severe 21β-hydroxylase deficiency can manifest during infancy with failure to thrive, vomiting, poor feeding, and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. However, urine pH would be < 5.5, and patients would be hyperkalemic as well as hyponatremic as a result of aldosterone deficiency (type 4 renal tubular acidosis). Clitoromegaly or ambiguous genitalia would also be present in this infant if she had severe 21β-hydroxylase deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids is the underlying pathology in maple syrup urine disease, which may manifest with poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, and failure to thrive. However, the onset of symptoms occurs during the early neonatal period, and patients have an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis (due to the accumulation of intermediate ketoacids). Moreover, the newborn screening test would have been positive, and the patient's urine would have a characteristic sickly sweet odor of maple syrup.

C) INCORRECT:

An inability of the ascending limb of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl- is seen in Bartter syndrome, which may manifest with preterm delivery, vomiting, a failure to thrive, and hypokalemia. Irritability and poor feeding may also occur as a result of severe dehydration (due to polyuria). However, there is no history to suggest polyuria (e.g., frequent changing of diapers), or evidence of severe dehydration in this patient (e.g., tenting of skin, sunken eyes, tachypnea, hypotension). Moreover, Bartter syndrome typically causes metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Inability of the proximal convoluted tubule to reabsorb HCO3- would result in type 2 RTA, which can manifest with a failure to thrive, vomiting, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, and hypokalemia. However, patients with type 2 RTA would typically have a urine pH < 5.5 (due to increased H+ secretion by the distal tubule in an attempt to correct metabolic acidosis).

E) INCORRECT:

A CFTR mutation is responsible for cystic fibrosis (CF), which may manifest with a failure to thrive. Irritability, vomiting, and poor feeding may also occur as a result of respiratory infections or intestinal obstruction. However, a cough or clinical features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring) are absent in this patient, and there is no history of abdominal distention or obstipation. Additionally, CF typically results in hypochloremia with respiratory acidosis and/or metabolic alkalosis. Lastly, a positive newborn screening test for CF was not reported.

F) CORRECT:

Type 1 RTA is associated with decreased activity of the H+/K+ATPase antiporter on the apical surface of intercalated cells, which inhibits the distal tubule from secreting H+and reabsorbing K+ from the lumen of the tubule. This subsequently results in hypokalemia and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with urine that cannot be acidified to a pH < 5.5. The most likely cause of type 1 RTA in an infant is an inherited genetic defect. However, an ultrasound is usually performed to rule out other causes, such as nephrocalcinosis, medullary sponge kidney, and reflux nephropathy. Treatment of type 1 RTA consists of alkalization therapy with orally administered sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate.
Image Description:

The connecting tubule is the most distal part of the distal tubule. The physiological function of the connecting tubule and the collecting duct is to fine-tune the composition of the urine, which can also be regulated by hormones (not shown here). There are different types of cells:

1) Principal cells (upper part of the image) reabsorb water via aquaporins and contribute to sodium resorption via aldosterone-controlled sodium channels.

2) Intercalated cells mainly participate in the regulation of blood pH and are divided into Type A/α and Type B/β cells. α-Intercalated cells (middle part of the image) secrete protons into the lumen and transport bicarbonate into the Interstitium. β-Intercalated cells (lower part of the image) transport protons into the Interstitium and secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

G) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) may result in vomiting, poor feeding, failure to thrive, and irritability during infancy. However, patients would have a raised serum ammonium level and respiratory alkalosis with tachypnea (due to stimulation of the respiratory center by hyperammonemia). Moreover, OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disease that primarily affects boys and typically presents during the neonatal period.
questions.hint: Failure to thrive in an infant with a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, a urine pH > 5.5, and hypokalemia is suggestive of renal tubular acidosis type 1 (type 1 RTA).

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-week history of fatigue and muscle weakness. She has not had fever or chills. One month ago, she was treated with amoxicillin for a urinary tract infection. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic low back pain. Her medications are insulin, enalapril, and acetaminophen. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


 Hemoglobin A1C

9.1%


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 Cl-

108 mEq/L


 K+

5.9 mEq/L


 HCO3-

20 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


 Glucose
190 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


 Osmolality
295 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 pH

5.1


 Blood
negative


 Glucose
+1


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency is characterized by decreased production of adrenocortical hormones (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and adrenal androgens). Patients with primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) typically present with hyperkalemia and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis due to hypoaldosteronism. However, hypoglycemia, rather than the hyperglycemia seen here, would be expected as a result of cortisol deficiency. Moreover, other features of adrenal insufficiency, such as hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and hyponatremia, are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) can be caused by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) as a result of inhibition of the angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction of the efferent arterioles, which decreases glomerular filtration rate. Prerenal AKI manifests with hyperkalemia, increased serum creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), as seen here. However, the BUN:creatinine ratio is typically > 20:1, whereas the ratio in this case is 14.7:1. Moreover, prerenal AKI would not explain this patient's normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Analgesic nephropathy is caused by long-term use of analgesic agents (e.g., acetaminophen in combination with NSAIDs) and can lead to type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is characterized by the inability of α-intercalated cells in the distal tubule to secrete hydrogen ions (H+). Although this results in hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, a urine pH > 5.5 is typical, as opposed to this patient's acidic urine, with a pH of 5.1. Moreover, type 1 RTA causes hypokalemia (not hyperkalemia, as seen here) as a result of renal potassium wasting due to impaired hydrogen secretion.

D) INCORRECT:

A hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) is seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. HHS is due to extreme hyperglycemia and can manifest with hyperkalemia and glucosuria, as seen here. However, HHS occurs with normal serum pH (rather than normal anion gap metabolic acidosis) and glucose ≥ 600 mg/dL, which in turn causes increased serum osmolality (e.g., usually > 320 mOsm/kg). Moreover, hyperglycemia leads to progressive volume depletion via osmotic diuresis, and patients typically present with polyuria, polydipsia, signs of volume depletion (dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), hypotension, and hypertonic hyponatremia, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fanconi syndrome is characterized by a general dysfunction of the proximal convoluted tubule, which is characterized by the inability of cells in the proximal convoluted tubule to reabsorb bicarbonate (type 2 renal tubular acidosis) and other compounds (e.g., potassium, glucose, phosphate, and amino acids). Fanconi syndrome can be caused by various drugs, including tetracyclines and aminoglycosides (but not penicillins, as in this case) and manifests with hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and a urine pH < 5.5. However, these findings are typically accompanied by hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

F) CORRECT:

Type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is caused by aldosterone deficiency and/or resistance in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting duct. This patient with poorly regulated type 2 diabetes mellitus and elevated creatinine most likely has diabetic nephropathy, which can cause hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism due to damage to the juxtaglomerular apparatus. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) diminish aldosterone release by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II and can thereby also cause type 4 RTA and worsen hyperkalemia. In the healthy nephron, aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium and hydrogen excretion; the relative deficiency of aldosterone causes the accumulation of excess potassium and hydrogen ions in the serum (explaining the mild hyperkalemia and acidosis). The urine is appropriately acidic, as the nephron is attempting to compensate for the acidic serum by reabsorbing bicarbonate, another hallmark of type 4 RTA. Treatment consists of furosemide to lower potassium and fludrocortisone as mineralocorticoid replacement.
questions.hint: This patient's hyperkalemia, normal anion gap, and acidic urine are most likely due to mineralocorticoid resistance.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and decreased urination. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

3.2 mEq/L


 Cl-

115 mEq/L


Mg2+

1.4 mg/dL


Urine



 pH
7.0


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.28 and a HCO3- concentration of 14 mEq/L. Prolonged treatment with which of the following drugs would best explain this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is an antimicrobial drug used in the treatment of urinary tract infections and pneumocystis pneumonia and as prophylaxis in patients with AIDS who have a reduced CD4 cell count. TMP-SMX can cause acute kidney injury, which manifests in the oliguric phase with decreased urination, hyperkalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. In contrast, this patient has hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in the treatment of altitude sickness, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis. This drug can cause a type 2 renal tubular acidosis, which is a hyperchloremic, hypokalemic, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Acetazolamide initially alkalinizes urine by promoting renal excretion of HCO3-. After the serum concentration of HCO3- equilibrates, reabsorption in the proximal tubule returns to normal, and urine pH typically becomes < 5.5. This patient has a urine pH of 7.0. Moreover, acetazolamide is a diuretic and causes increased, not decreased, urine output.

C) INCORRECT:

Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome). Eplerenone decreases Na+ reabsorption and causes H2O retention, thereby increasing urine output and decreasing serum Na+ concentrations. By causing aldosterone resistance, it can result in the development of a type 4 renal tubular acidosis, which is a hyperchloremic, hyperkalemic, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis associated with a urine pH < 5.5. This patient has decreased urine output, hypokalemia, and a urine pH of 7.0.

D) CORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal drug used in the treatment of severe, systemic fungal infections. Amphotericin B reacts with ergosterol and disrupts fungal cell membranes. Because of nonspecific binding, it can also bind to cholesterol found in human cells, which leads to several adverse effects. Infusion-related reactions, which manifest with nausea, vomiting, and chills, are common. Additional adverse effects include fever, headache, and nephrotoxicity. In addition to acute kidney injury, patients often develop a type 1 renal tubular acidosis, a hyperchloremic, hypokalemic, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis with an associated urine pH > 5.5, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Heparin is an antithrombin activator used for anticoagulation. It has a direct toxic effect on adrenal zona glomerulosa cells. As a result, heparin therapy can lead to a decreased concentration of aldosterone and the development of a type 4 renal tubular acidosis, which is a hyperchloremic, hyperkalemic, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis associated with a urine pH < 5.5. This patient has hypokalemia and a urine pH of 7.0.
questions.hint: Anion gap is usually calculated as [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]), and a range of 6–12 mmol/L is normal. This patient's normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (anion gap = 7 mmol/L), urine pH > 5.5, and hypokalemia are suggestive of type 1 renal tubular acidosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of generalized weakness. He also reports increased urination and thirst. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. His only medication is metformin. Serum studies show:


Na+

134 mEq/L


Cl-

110 mEq/L


K+
5.6 mEq/L


HCO3-

19 mEq/L


Glucose
135 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.6 mg/dL


Urine pH is 5.1. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired HCO3- reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Impaired H+ secretion in the distal tubule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ethylene glycol intoxication can cause metabolic derangements similar to this patient's increased creatinine and potassium levels. However, metabolizing ethylene glycol leads to increased formation of ketone bodies, which results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis and lacks features of ethylene glycol intoxication such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and altered mental status.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 2 RTA occurs when proximal convoluted tubule cells are unable to reabsorb bicarbonate (HCO3-). Causes of type 2 RTA include Fanconi syndrome, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide), and multiple myeloma. While type 2 RTA results in hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and a decreased urine pH (< 5.5), both of which are seen in this patient, it would not be expected to cause hyperkalemia.

C) CORRECT:

Type 4 RTA is most commonly caused by aldosterone deficiency (e.g., due to adrenal insufficiency, NSAID use, hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism from diabetic nephropathy) or aldosterone resistance (e.g., due to spironolactone use, obstructive nephropathy). Aldosterone deficiency results in impaired sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubules, which causes both hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia because of changes in electronegativity across the tubular lumen. Hyperkalemia inhibits urine NH4+ excretion, further exacerbating acidosis and manifesting with low urine pH. Given the patient's type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease, his type 4 RTA is most likely due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism.

D) INCORRECT:

Type 1 RTA occurs when intercalated cells in the distal tubule are unable to secrete hydrogen ions (H+), leading to metabolic acidosis, increased urine pH (> 5.5), and hypokalemia. Causes of type 1 RTA include analgesic nephropathy and amphotericin B toxicity. This patient has neither high urine pH nor hypokalemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactic acidosis can cause metabolic acidosis and, very rarely, can occur in patients with renal insufficiency who use metformin. However, lactic acidosis results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis, not the normal anion gap metabolic acidosis seen in this patient. It would also not explain the patient's low urine pH.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum cortisol levels are seen in patients with adrenal insufficiency, which can manifest with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and elevated creatinine. However, the patient's hyperglycemia makes adrenal insufficiency very unlikely, as patients with cortisol deficiency usually also have hypoglycemia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, a normal serum anion gap, hyperkalemia, and decreased urine pH. Together with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease, these features suggest type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA).

questions.text:
A 1-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of persistent irritability and crying. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. His mother reports that she nurses him frequently and changes his diapers 18–20 times per day. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a triangular face with a prominent forehead and large, protruding ears. Serum studies show:


Na+

129 mEq/L


K+

2.8 mEq/L


Cl-

90 mEq/L


Ca2+

8.0 mg/dL


HCO3-

32 mEq/L


Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.51. The effects of this patient's condition are most similar to the long-term administration of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that inhibits Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct and can cause polyuria, polydipsia, failure to thrive, and hyponatremia, each of which is seen in this case. However, triamterene therapy causes hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia) and mimics type 4 renal tubular acidosis, not Bartter syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Fludrocortisone is a mineralocorticoid that increases Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion in the collecting ducts, which results in hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and normal or slightly elevated serum Na+ concentration (not hyponatremia). It does not cause hypocalcemia, polydipsia, or polyuria. Fludrocortisone therapy mimics Liddle syndrome and primary hyperaldosteronism, not Bartter syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Bumetanide is a loop diuretic that blocks Na+/K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle. Loop diuretics thus increase the excretion of Na+, K+, and Cl-. Decreased transport of Na+ and K+ reduces the electrochemical gradient in the loop of Henle, which decreases passive reabsorption of Ca2+ and Mg2+. As a result, loop diuretic therapy can cause electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia) and metabolic alkalosis. These manifestations mimic Bartter syndrome.

Some patients with Bartter syndrome develop hyperuricemia and hypophosphatemia. The dysmorphic facial features seen in this patient are not always present in Bartter syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Tolvaptan is an ADH receptor antagonist that increases free water loss in urine and can cause polydipsia, polyuria, hypokalemia, contraction metabolic alkalosis, and hypernatremia (not hyponatremia). It does not cause hypocalcemia. Tolvaptan therapy mimics diabetes insipidus, not Bartter syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits Na+ and Cl- reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules (DCT). Thiazide diuretic therapy can cause hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis, each of which is seen in this case. However, thiazide diuretic therapy causes hypercalcemia (not hypocalcemia) because inhibited Na+ reabsorption in the DCT increases the activity of Na+/Ca2+ exchangers on these cells. These manifestations mimic Gitelman syndrome, not Bartter syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that increases renal excretion of Na+ and bicarbonate and can cause polydipsia, polyuria, hypokalemia, hyperchloremia (not hypochloremia) and metabolic acidosis (not metabolic alkalosis). Acetazolamide therapy mimics type 2 renal tubular acidosis, not Bartter syndrome.

G) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that increases free water loss in urine. Highly elevated concentrations of mannitol in the serum (e.g., from high doses in the setting of renal failure) cause extracellular movement of water and K+, which results in hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis (not metabolic alkalosis), and hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia). Mannitol therapy mimics conditions that cause osmotic diuresis (e.g., glucosuria due to diabetes mellitus), not Bartter syndrome.
questions.hint: This newborn has Bartter syndrome, which causes defects in the reabsorption of electrolytes in the ascending loop of Henle. This condition is associated with polyhydramnios in utero and preterm delivery. It manifests with polydipsia, polyuria, failure to thrive, dysmorphic facies, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypocalcemia, and metabolic alkalosis, each of which is seen in this case.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 7-month history of fatigue, recurrent leg cramps, and increased urinary frequency. His pulse is 94/min and blood pressure is 118/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

130 mEq/L


K+

2.8 mEq/L


Cl-

92 mEq/L


Mg2+

1.1 mg/dL


Ca2+

10.6 mg/dL


Albumin
5.2 g/dL


Urine



Ca2+

70 mg/24 h


Cl-

375 mEq/24h (N = 110–250)


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.55 and an HCO3- concentration of 45 mEq/L. Impaired function of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defects in the ascending loop of Henle can cause Bartter syndrome, which may manifest with polyuria and muscle cramps. Laboratory findings in Bartter syndrome include hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and metabolic alkalosis, all of which are seen here. However, Bartter syndrome causes increased urinary loss of calcium and hypocalcemia rather than hypocalciuria and hypercalcemia, which are seen in this patient. Moreover, patients with this condition typically present in early childhood.

B) CORRECT:

Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular defect caused by the impaired functioning of the Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule. Symptoms such as fatigue, muscle cramps, polyuria, and chondrocalcinosis typically arise in late childhood and can be attributed to the associated electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, and hypocalciuria). In addition, Gitelman syndrome causes metabolic alkalosis due to mild RAAS activation that occurs in response to natriuresis and volume depletion. Treatment for Gitelman syndrome consists of potassium supplementation and a potassium-sparing diuretic (e.g., spironolactone, amiloride).

Because thiazide diuretics target the Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule, patients with Gitelman syndrome have a blunted response to these agents, with the response being measured as the fractional clearance of chloride. Alternatively, these patients will have a normal response to loop diuretics, which target the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

C) INCORRECT:

The thin descending loop of Henle is the site of ultrafiltrate concentration, which makes the urine hypertonic. The descending loop is impermeable to sodium, chloride, and urea. This enables free water within the tubules to be passively reabsorbed into the interstitium via an osmotic gradient created by medullary hypertonicity. Defects of the descending loop of Henle are more likely to lead to the inability to concentrate urine rather than natriuresis, which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, renal tubular disorders do not typically involve the descending loop of Henle.

D) INCORRECT:

Defects in the epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) of the collecting duct cause Liddle syndrome, which may manifest with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. However, Liddle syndrome causes increased reuptake of water and sodium (due to impaired degradation of ENaCs), which would not explain this patient's natriuresis and hypocalciuria. Furthermore, Liddle syndrome usually presents in childhood and is associated with hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Defects in the proximal convoluted tubule can lead to Fanconi syndrome, which may manifest with muscle cramping and hypokalemia. However, Fanconi syndrome causes normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (type 2 renal tubular acidosis) and hypocalcemia rather than the metabolic alkalosis and hypercalcemia seen in this patient. Furthermore, clinical features of Fanconi syndrome, which include rickets/osteomalacia and stunted growth, are not seen here.
questions.hint: Metabolic alkalosis with high urine chloride raises suspicion for a resorption defect in the renal tubules. In addition, this patient's electrolyte abnormalities mimic chronic thiazide diuretic ingestion.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 12 months
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My son seems much smaller than other kids of his age.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought by his mother because of concerns about physical development
shows little interest in walking, playing, or engaging with family members
drinks a lot of fluid; has 10+ wet diapers per day
no vomiting or diarrhea

Past Medical History:
born at 39 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 3400 g (54th %ile) and 51 cm (72th %ile) after an uncomplicated pregnancy
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family history:
mother age 26 years, father age 30 years: alive with no chronic conditions
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Lt
Wt
BMI


37.1°C(98.8°F)
104/min
35/min
90/54 mm Hg
-
71 cm(2 ft 4 in)2nd %ile
8.4 kg(18 lb 8 oz)10th %ile
-



Appearance: lying on examination bed; no acute distress
Skin: no rashes 
HEENT: PERRLA; ear canal clear and tympanic membrane normal
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: soft; nontender; normoactive bowel sounds; no hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: normal movement; no edema
Neurologic: normal muscle tone; no tremors

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



 Hematocrit
41%


 Hemoglobin
13.8 mg/dL


 WBC
6000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

138 mEq/L


 K+

3.2 mEq/L


 Cl-

115 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL


 Glucose
80 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 TSH
3.1 μU/mL


Arterial blood gas analysis



 pH

7.29


 pCO2

34 mm Hg


 pO2

98 mm Hg


 HCO3-

16 mEq/L


Urine



 pH

5.2


 Na+

19 mEq/L


 K+

18 mEq/L


 Cl-

40 mEq/L


 Glucose
negative



Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated in severe metabolic acidosis (serum pH < 7.1 or serum bicarbonate levels < 12 mmol/L), severe hyperkalemia, symptomatic uremia, certain poisonings (e.g., ethylene glycol toxicity, methanol toxicity) or diuretic-resistant fluid overload, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase in multiple organs and can be used to treat chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis, altitude sickness with respiratory alkalosis, acute glaucoma, and idiopathic intracerebral hypertension. Because acetazolamide increases bicarbonate and potassium elimination in the kidneys, it is contraindicated in hypokalemia and may itself cause type 2 RTA.

C) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is indicated as an alkali therapy in type 1 RTA, which manifests similarly but typically results in a urine pH > 5.5 and a positive urine anion gap. In type 2 RTA, therapy with sodium bicarbonate initially increases bicarbonaturia, which stimulates potassium secretion in the distal tubule and worsens hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

RTA types 1 and 2 are treated with alkali therapy to correct metabolic acidosis and promote normal growth. Potassium citrate is the alkali therapy of choice in isolated type 2 RTA to avoid exacerbating hypokalemia. In type 2 RTA, therapy with sodium bicarbonate initially increases bicarbonaturia, which stimulates potassium secretion in the distal tubule and worsens hypokalemia. This urinary potassium loss can be mitigated by using potassium citrate instead of, or in combination with, other alkali preparations. For drug-induced RTA (e.g., caused by acetazolamide), the offending agent should be discontinued. Thiazide diuretics can increase bicarbonate reabsorption if alkali therapy is ineffective or not tolerated. The absence of glucosuria in this patient suggests type 2 RTA without Fanconi syndrome. Therapy for Fanconi syndrome is similar to that of isolated type 2 RTA but includes the management of impaired reabsorption of glucose, phosphate, and amino acids.

E) INCORRECT:

Fludrocortisone is indicated in type 4 RTA, which may result from aldosterone deficiency or resistance. Type 4 RTA is characterized by hyperkalemia and a positive urine anion gap; this patient has hypokalemia and a negative urine anion gap.
questions.hint: Failure to thrive, polyuria, polydipsia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis are features of renal tubular acidosis. Hypokalemia with a urine pH < 5.5 and a negative urine anion gap indicates proximal renal tubular acidosis (type 2 RTA).

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with HIV presents for follow-up of abnormal findings on a recent bone mineral density evaluation: T scores of −5.8 at the lumbar spine and −5.5 at the femoral neck.
She reports no history of fragility fractures but a 6-month history of worsening bone pain in her arms, back, chest, and thighs. Her medications include tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine and efavirenz.
On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation over the spine and tibiae. Muscle strength is 4+ of 5 in the proximal muscle groups and 5 of 5 in the distal muscle groups.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
142
136–145



Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.1
3.5–5.0



Chloride (mEq/liter)
112
98–106



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
19
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
10
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


Glucose (mg/dL)
113
70–100


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.6
9.0–10.5



Phosphorus (mg/dL)
1.0
3.0–4.5


Magnesium (mg/dL)
1.9
1.8–3.0


CD4-cell count (per mm3)
532
400–1600


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
32
30–80


Intact parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
33
10–60


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
243
30–120


Urinalysis shows a pH of 5.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), 1+ protein, and 2+ glucose. Fractional excretion of phosphate (FEPhos) based on a random urine specimen is 32%.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s low bone mineral density?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypophosphatasia is a genetic disorder associated with low phosphate levels, metabolic bone disease, and a very low alkaline phosphatase level.

B) CORRECT:

Fanconi syndrome is caused by dysfunction of the proximal renal tubule leading to increased urinary losses of solutes (amino acids, bicarbonate, glucose, potassium, and phosphate) that are normally reabsorbed in that tubule.

Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) can cause damage to the proximal renal tubule. TDF is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the proximal tubule via transport through the cell. Accumulation of TDF can lead to disruption of mitochondrial DNA in proximal tubule cells, and this limits the function of these cells, which normally play a role in reabsorption of most of the urinary filtrate.

The first sign of proximal tubule dysfunction is typically phosphate wasting and then hypophosphatemia, but the presence of diffuse abnormalities is referred to as Fanconi syndrome. Fanconi syndrome may include glycosuria with normal blood glucose levels, hypokalemia with urinary potassium losses, and a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Despite the tubular dysfunction, patients with this syndrome can typically still make acidic urine (except during bicarbonate intake) because the distal nephron is the key location of urinary acidification.

Normally, most of the filtered phosphate is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, and the fractional excretion of phosphate (FEPhos) is <20%. In the setting of hypophosphatemia, the FEPhos should be ≤5%. This patient’s high FEPhos is consistent with renal phosphate wasting. Urinary phosphate losses can lead to impaired mineralization of bone (osteomalacia) with bone pain and reduced bone mineral density.

Normal or high urinary pH and normal or high potassium and phosphate excretion in a patient with metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia confirms tubular dysfunction.

Fanconi syndrome is uncommon in adults; it may be acquired secondary to a monoclonal gammopathy, from exposure to certain medications (including TDF and ifosfamide), or from heavy-metal poisoning. The treatment is withdrawal of the offending agent and provision of electrolyte replacement. Of note, tenofovir alafenamide has been well tolerated in patients with prior toxicity from TDF.

High FEPhos is appropriate in the setting of secondary hyperparathyroidism, as with reduced vitamin D levels, but this patient has both normal 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels and normal parathyroid hormone levels.

Key learning point: Osteomalacia with concomitant hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, glycosuria, and proteinuria is most consistent with a diagnosis of Fanconi syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease is often associated with disorders of mineral and bone metabolism, but this typically occurs after years of reduced kidney function and typically manifests with high levels of parathyroid hormone along with normal or high blood phosphate levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Other conditions can cause secondary osteoporosis or hypophosphatemia but usually without the other metabolic abnormalities seen in this patient. These conditions include mastocytosis, hungry bone syndrome (hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia caused by rapid deposition of calcium phosphate crystals into bone after parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism), and tumor-induced osteomalacia (isolated phosphaturia caused by fibroblast growth factor 23 secreted by mesenchymal tumors).

E) INCORRECT:

Other conditions can cause secondary osteoporosis or hypophosphatemia but usually without the other metabolic abnormalities seen in this patient. These conditions include mastocytosis, hungry bone syndrome (hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia caused by rapid deposition of calcium phosphate crystals into bone after parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism), and tumor-induced osteomalacia (isolated phosphaturia caused by fibroblast growth factor 23 secreted by mesenchymal tumors).

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents with pain in her lower extremities that is related to recurrent, poorly healing stress fractures and that limits her activity. Her medical history is also notable for short stature, arthritis, recurrent stress fractures, and dental abscesses. She has not had any recent trauma. Her family history is remarkable for short stature, abscesses, and fractures in her father and two sisters but not in her three brothers. Her sister’s son has rickets, but her other nieces and nephews are unaffected.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
10.4
9.0–10.5



Phosphorus (mg/dL)
1.9
3.0–4.5


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
56
10–60


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
32
30–80


1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (pg/mL)
28
25–45


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
187
30–120


Albumin (g/dL)
4.2
3.5–5.5


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
16
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following medications is indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excess calcium supplementation should be avoided to prevent the complication of hypercalcemia.

B) CORRECT:

The laboratory findings in this patient reveal hypophosphatemia in the setting of normal levels of calcium and 25-hydroxyvitamin D, as well as low-to-normal 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels, consistent with renal phosphate wasting. The symptoms of recurrent stress fractures, arthritis, and dental abscesses all suggest hypophosphatemia and are the most likely cause of the patient’s current pain. Her family history is consistent with an X-linked dominant disorder, making X-linked hypophosphatemia the most likely diagnosis.

Genetic testing for a mutation in PHEX (the phosphate-regulating gene with homologies to endopeptidase on the X chromosome) can confirm the diagnosis of X-linked hypophosphatemia. The primary defect in X-linked hypophosphatemia is impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate, attributed in part to elevations in fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF-23), which leads to urinary wasting of phosphate.

X-linked hypophosphatemia has, until recently, been treated with a combination of phosphate and calcitriol; however, this therapy does not treat the underlying pathophysiology, may be poorly tolerated, and leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism and, sometimes, nephrocalcinosis. Therefore, in children and in symptomatic adults, the first-line treatment is now generally felt to be burosumab, a monoclonal antibody to FGF-23. This therapy reduces urinary phosphate loss, thus normalizing serum phosphate levels, and improves fracture healing rates. Given the high cost of this medication, it is generally not used in adults with limited symptoms.

Key learning point: Symptomatic X-linked hypophosphatemia is treated with the administration of phosphate and burosumab, a monoclonal antibody to fibroblast growth factor 23.

C) INCORRECT:

Most vitamin D preparations, including ergocalciferol, are not useful treatments for patients with X-linked hypophosphatemia because these patients lack adequate 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity; calcitriol (which is already hydroxylated) may be used in milder cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Most vitamin D preparations, including cholecalciferol, are not useful treatments for patients with X-linked hypophosphatemia because these patients lack adequate 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity; calcitriol (which is already hydroxylated) may be used in milder cases.

E) INCORRECT:

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent approved for treating secondary hyperparathyroidism and hypercalcemia associated with parathyroid carcinoma; it is not indicated for treating X-linked hypophosphatemia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents for a routine office visit. He feels well. His current medications are metformin 1000 mg twice daily, atenolol 50 mg daily, and amlodipine 10 mg daily.
He has a blood pressure of 151/83 mm Hg while sitting, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.2°C. His physical examination is remarkable for trace edema in the lower extremities.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.9 (now)5.3 (1 year ago)
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
108
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
21
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
12
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.2
0.8–1.3


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.9
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9600
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
190,000
150,000–350,000


Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
161
70–100


Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (mg/g)
25
<30


In addition to a low-potassium diet, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate to control this patient’s persistent hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has hyperkalemia that is out of proportion to his kidney dysfunction. This is a common problem in older patients and in those with diabetes mellitus. The pattern seems to reflect a blunted response to hyperkalemia and has been described as hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism or designated type 4 renal tubular acidosis (RTA). In this disorder, the hyperkalemia is a more prominent issue than the nongap metabolic acidosis, which tends to be mild if present at all. This condition is the most common type of RTA.

Multiple medications interfere with the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis and can produce this pattern of electrolytes. For example:

• Beta-blockers and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs can blunt the release of renin.
• Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers limit the release of aldosterone.
• Heparin impairs aldosterone production.

The diagnosis of type 4 RTA is made on clinical grounds rather than measurement of renin and aldosterone levels. Also, importantly, even though the hyperkalemia suggests hypoaldosteronism, patients with this condition frequently have hypertension or edema, so use of a mineralocorticoid for treatment is not recommended. Thus, fludrocortisone, a synthetic analogue of aldosterone, might improve this patient’s serum potassium level, but it is likely to worsen his blood pressure and edema.

Instead, a thiazide diuretic, such as chlorthalidone, is the most appropriate therapy for this patient because it would not only lower his serum potassium level but also help reduce the volume overload evident on examination by hypertension and mild edema.

Key learning point: The best next step in treating chronic hyperkalemia in a patient with type 4 renal tubular acidosis in the setting of type 2 diabetes and hypertension is initiation of a thiazide diuretic.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous saline might help promote potassium secretion but is likely to worsen the patient’s volume expansion and would not address the chronic nature of this problem.

C) INCORRECT:

Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (SPS), an ion-exchange resin, exchanges potassium for sodium in the colon. This agent is appropriate for treatment of acute severe hyperkalemia (potassium levels >6.0 mEq/liter) when renal excretion is reduced and when it is unlikely that the potassium can be lowered rapidly by other means, such as diuretics or a rapid improvement in renal function. SPS was developed before the U.S. Food and Drug Administration required that manufacturers prove efficacy and safety. After SPS was introduced, cases of colonic necrosis were reported, which may be related to the concomitant use of sorbitol, as osmotic laxative. Although premixed preparations with 70% sorbitol are no longer available, cases of colonic necrosis have been reported with the 33% formulation as well. For this reason and because the data regarding efficacy is limited, SPS should be used only cautiously. Of note, cation exchange resins may interfere with absorption of medications. Two new agents have recently been approved for chronic hyperkalemia: patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate.

D) INCORRECT:

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that would worsen hyperkalemia and is therefore not recommended in this setting.

E) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of type 4 RTA is made on clinical grounds rather than measurement of renin and aldosterone levels. Also, importantly, even though the hyperkalemia suggests hypoaldosteronism, patients with this condition frequently have hypertension or edema, so use of a mineralocorticoid for treatment is not recommended. Thus, fludrocortisone, a synthetic analogue of aldosterone, might improve this patient’s serum potassium level, but it is likely to worsen his blood pressure and edema.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl presents with new onset of difficulty walking. Her parents report that she first started walking at age 13 months and was doing so normally until 2 weeks ago, when she started complaining of bilateral leg pain after long periods of walking. For the past 2 days, she has been refusing to walk. Her speech and fine motor development are normal. She has had no recent fevers or injuries. Her family history is notable for bilateral knee pain in her mother since age 22 and for short stature in her mother, maternal aunt, and maternal grandmother.
On examination, the patient’s weight is at the 20th percentile, and her height is at the 1st percentile. Both of her lower extremities show significant bowing, and both wrists appear widened.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.5
8.8–10.8


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
2.8
4.5–6.5


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
33
30–60


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
620
100–320


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
54
10–60


A lower-extremity radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency is the most common cause of rickets worldwide. Laboratory findings of nutritional rickets include low serum calcium and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels, as well as an elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) level.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic renal insufficiency can also lead to a reduction in 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D because of reduced 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity and subsequent secondary hyperparathyroidism; the phosphate level is often elevated. In this patient, the PTH level was normal, and the serum phosphate level was low.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 1 collagen gene mutations cause osteogenesis imperfecta, which can cause bone deformities and fractures but does not cause rachitic changes at the growth plate. Patients with this condition typically have normal serum phosphate levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypocalcemic rickets can also be caused by 1-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency, which is the enzyme that converts inactive 25-hydroxyvitamin D to active 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Typical laboratory findings for 1-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency include a low calcium level, elevated PTH level, low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D level, and normal 25-hydroxyvitamin D level.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has classic features of rickets, including bowed legs, widened wrists, leg pain, short stature, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase level. Her lower-extremity radiograph shows widening, cupping, and fraying of the metaphysis, also consistent with rickets.

Rickets can be caused by hypocalcemia or hypophosphatemia, from either nutritional deficiencies (in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate) or genetic mutations that affect bone mineral metabolism. This patient’s laboratory results show hypophosphatemia with normal calcium and vitamin D levels, making hypophosphatemic rickets the most likely cause of her symptoms. Her family history of short stature and joint pain suggests a genetic cause; X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets related to a mutation in the PHEX gene is the most common familial form of hypophosphatemic rickets. Patients with this mutation, which is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern, have reduced tubular reabsorption of phosphate, leading to hypophosphatemia.

Familial hypophosphatemic rickets is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical findings. It can be treated with oral phosphate repletion plus high-dose calcitriol (the activated form of vitamin D). Calcitriol (rather than ergocalciferol) is required because of decreased synthesis and increased catabolism of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D; it also helps to limit the rise in PTH associated with phosphate repletion. Although serum phosphate levels may remain low, treatment goals in hypophosphatemic rickets include improved growth, healing of rachitic skeletal changes, and a decrease in skeletal deformities. Nephrocalcinosis is a potential adverse effect of treatment with calcitriol, and urinary calcium excretion should be monitored routinely, along with periodic renal ultrasounds. Burosumab has recently been approved for the treatment of X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets and has shown beneficial results including correction of hypophosphatemia, improved growth, and reductions in pain; however, this medication is very costly.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of rickets in a child with a low serum phosphate level is X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets related to a mutation in the PHEX gene.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 3-month-old girl who is brought to your clinic because of poor feeding, irritability, and vomiting for 2 weeks. She was born at 36 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 5th percentile for length and 3rd percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 49/min. Physical and neurologic examinations are normal. Laboratory studies show the following:


Sodium (Na), blood
138 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood

3.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Chloride (Cl), blood
115 mmol/L (98–107)


Ammonia, blood
23 μmol/L (≤35)


pH, urine

6.9 (5.0–8.5)


Blood, urine
Negative


Glucose, urine
Negative


Protein, urine
Negative


pH, arterial blood

7.28 (7.38–7.46)


Po2, arterial blood
96 mm Hg (83–116)


Bicarbonate (HCO3), arterial blood

12 mmol/L (22–27)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Inability of the distal tubule to secrete H+.
Inability of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl-.
Inability of the proximal tubule to reabsorb HCO3-.
Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Type 1 RTA is associated with decreased activity of the H+/K+ATPase antiporter on the apical surface of intercalated cells, which inhibits the distal tubule from secreting H+and reabsorbing K+ from the lumen of the tubule. This subsequently results in hypokalemia and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with urine that cannot be acidified to a pH < 5.5. The most likely cause of type 1 RTA in an infant is an inherited genetic defect. However, an ultrasound is usually performed to rule out other causes, such as nephrocalcinosis, medullary sponge kidney, and reflux nephropathy. Treatment of type 1 RTA consists of alkalization therapy with orally administered sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate.

Key learning point: Type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis is caused by the inability of the distal tubule to secrete hydrogen ions, leading to non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and inappropriately alkaline urine (pH >5.5).
Image Description:

The connecting tubule is the most distal part of the distal tubule. The physiological function of the connecting tubule and the collecting duct is to fine-tune the composition of the urine, which can also be regulated by hormones (not shown here). There are different types of cells:

1) Principal cells (upper part of the image) reabsorb water via aquaporins and contribute to sodium resorption via aldosterone-controlled sodium channels.

2) Intercalated cells mainly participate in the regulation of blood pH and are divided into Type A/α and Type B/β cells. α-Intercalated cells (middle part of the image) secrete protons into the lumen and transport bicarbonate into the Interstitium. β-Intercalated cells (lower part of the image) transport protons into the Interstitium and secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

B) INCORRECT:

An inability of the ascending limb of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl- is seen in Bartter syndrome, which may manifest with preterm delivery, vomiting, a failure to thrive, and hypokalemia. Irritability and poor feeding may also occur as a result of severe dehydration (due to polyuria). However, there is no history to suggest polyuria (e.g., frequent changing of diapers), or evidence of severe dehydration in this patient (e.g., tenting of skin, sunken eyes, tachypnea, hypotension). Moreover, Bartter syndrome typically causes metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Inability of the proximal convoluted tubule to reabsorb HCO3- would result in type 2 RTA, which can manifest with a failure to thrive, vomiting, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, and hypokalemia. However, patients with type 2 RTA would typically have a urine pH < 5.5 (due to increased H+ secretion by the distal tubule in an attempt to correct metabolic acidosis).

D) INCORRECT:

A CFTR mutation is responsible for cystic fibrosis (CF), which may manifest with a failure to thrive. Irritability, vomiting, and poor feeding may also occur as a result of respiratory infections or intestinal obstruction. However, a cough or clinical features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring) are absent in this patient, and there is no history of abdominal distention or obstipation. Additionally, CF typically results in hypochloremia with respiratory acidosis and/or metabolic alkalosis. Lastly, a positive newborn screening test for CF was not reported.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids is the underlying pathology in maple syrup urine disease, which may manifest with poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, and failure to thrive. However, the onset of symptoms occurs during the early neonatal period, and patients have an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis (due to the accumulation of intermediate ketoacids). Moreover, the newborn screening test would have been positive, and the patient's urine would have a characteristic sickly sweet odor of maple syrup.
questions.hint: Failure to thrive in an infant with a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, a urine pH > 5.5, and hypokalemia is suggestive of renal tubular acidosis type 1 (type 1 RTA).
